Award.AwardTitle: Thermodynamics of Computation in Chemical and Biological Systems to be held August 14-16, 2017 at SFI
Award.AbstractNarration:
The workshop "Thermodynamics of computation in chemical and biological systems" at the Santa Fe Institute (SFI) will explore the role of both thermodynamics and computation in constraining biological processes, evolution, and metabolism. The workshop will be held over two-and-a-half days investigating the connection between thermodynamics and computation in a variety of topics including: pure computer science, the statistical mechanics of computation, chemical computers, the thermodynamics and computation of organisms. A synthesis of these topics will be necessary to more fully understand the general features of the thermodynamics of computation. In particular, understanding the fundamental aspects of the computations and energetics of life explicitly requires a treatment of each of the listed topics. Several graduate students and postdocs will participate in the meeting and the presentations and discussions will further their training and provide an array of new collaborations and opportunities for them in their research. An SFI NSF REU student will be co-mentored this summer on a project focused on the thermodynamics of biological computation. In addition, two of the co-organizers will present the new ideas discussed at the workshop to both the general public and scientific community.

The workshop will connect three sub-disciplines - statistical physics, computation and biological and chemical computers - to each other in an attempt to provide the field with deeper theoretical coherence and connection. In particular, there is the need to migrate computer science and statistical physics tools for use in biological and chemical computers, and in turn, to use the biological and chemical systems to inspire new theoretical questions and techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The thermodynamic costs of performing computation play a major role in biological computation. For example, ~20% of the calories burned by a human are used by their brain - which does nothing but compute. This is a massive reproductive fitness penalty. Indeed, one of the leading contenders for which development in hominin evolution allowed us to develop into homo sapiens is the discovery of fire, since that allowed us to cook meat and tubers, and thereby for the first time release enough calories from our food sources to power our brains. Despite this huge fitness cost, no current evolutionary theory accounts for the thermodynamic consequences of computation. It also seems that minimizing the thermodynamic costs of computation has been a major factor in evolution?s selection of the chemical networks in all biological organisms, not just hominin brains. In particular, simply dividing the rate of computation in the entire biosphere by the rate of free energy incident on the earth in sunlight shows that the biosphere as a whole performs computation with a thermodynamic efficiency orders of magnitude greater than our current supercomputers.

This workshop connected three sub-disciplines - statistical physics, computation, and biological and chemical computers - to each other in order to provide Thermodynamics of Computation in Biological Systems with deeper theoretical coherence and connection. In particular, the workshop addressed the need to migrate computer science and statistical physics tools for use in biological and chemical computers, and in turn, to use the biological and chemical systems to inspire new theoretical questions and techniques.

The workshop also helped create a new community of interacting scientists that involves theorists spanning pure computer science to mathematical biology and experimentalists who are designing biological systems at a broad range of scales. Several key graduate students and postdocs attended the meeting and the presentations and discussions furthered their training and provided an array of new collaborations and opportunities for them in their research.

In addition, two of the co-organizers have been actively engaged in presenting these ideas to both the general public and scientific community.
